body: Have you given up on the idea of getting the maximum name length in the constructor and using that? Because you have code commented out there.

I tried getting maxPowerNameWidth in constructor but couldn't do it. maxPlayerNameWidth could be in constructor but in the current version the texts align dynamically. So when a player with a long name doesn't build a support power, it won't be considered in alignment. But to do that this calculates maxPlayerNameWidth every tick.. So if dynamic alignment is not necessary, it could be done using the commented line in constructor.

Which one is better?

Dynamic alignment is better in this case.

Can we get a better name for Line and change it to a struct please?

On 2015-07-02, at 2:14 PM, Deniz notifications@github.com wrote:

> I tried getting maxPowerNameWidth in constructor but couldn't do it. maxPlayerNameWidth could be in constructor but this way the texts align dynamically. So when a player with a long name doesn't build a support power, it won't be considered in alignment. But to do that this calculates maxPlayerNameWidth every tick.. So if dynamic alignment is not necessary, it could be done using the commented line in constructor.
> 
> Which one is better?
> 
> â€•
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.

How should it be named? I thought line is the most fitting because that's what it represents. Any other suggestions?

And isn't class better than struct because it's passed by reference? Although it isn't passed to any method here, just added to a list. So it would probably make no difference? Should I change it to struct?
I could rename Line to Text...

And actually you can't change teams during game. Stance change in diplomacy window doesn't change player's team, only individual stances to other players... So I can move playersByTeam definition to the constructor.

But would it make a difference? Because it's an enumerable, would it be queried every time it is accessed? Is there a way to cache IOrderedEnumerable<IGrouping<int, Player>> ? Also is the ordering necessary there or would GroupBy already be in team order?

This looks like a more complicated version of [this](https://github.com/penev92/OpenRA/blob/ba6b3b8d4315750056db5fa816078289b87c4d53/OpenRA.Mods.Common/Widgets/SupportPowerTimerWidget.cs).
What are the benefits of this one over that?
I don't know, I haven't tested that.
Can Draw() execute before the first Tick()?

OK, I'm going to be blunt.

You already had a PR about this that was way more complicated that it needed to be. Because of that a lot of developers spent _a lot_ of time on it, including myself. _Then_, at one point, it reached a dead end. Instead of just closing it, I decided to give it a last chance, and spent around four hours of my time to rewrite it in a much simpler way. (Please keep in mind that even before I did so my opinion was that enough time was wasted on the PR by so many people for no gain.) Ultimately the PR was closed because you didn't want to use my suggested solution.

Now you are opening a new PR about the same thing (which is more than likely unfinished feature-wise). The code looks like a slightly more complicated version of the code I suggested for your previous PR, plus a (unnecessary?) `Tick()` method.
You say that you "haven't even tested" my suggested code. (?)

In light of that, I am going to -1 any solution that is more complicated than the one I proposed, unless you can explain how it is better than mine.
Why didn't you open a new pr with your version?

Because I don't consider this as something important, and definitely not something that justifies so many people wasting so much time on. And I still don't. So either we resolve this in a reasonable timeframe this time around, or I will close it.
Also because everyone else seems to be OK with the current state of the timers.

Are Tick() and Draw() methods synchronized? What happens when the game is paused? Tick() stops but Draw() continues, right? So it is better to put game state dependent code in Tick() and leave only drawing code in Draw() to minimize calculations.

If you don't consider this important and don't think this feature should be implemented, then why did you waste so much time, as you put it? Why did you write your own version and then not open a pull request?

> Instead of just closing it, I decided to give it a last chance

I figured that was the polite thing to do.
Don't get me wrong, I wanted to just close it and stop wasting everyone's time. And I definitely didn't want to spend 2 hours trying to figure out what your code does and 2 more simplifying it.
Ok, so you have the code that implements team grouping? Open a PR and if that's better than this one, it can be reviewed and merged...

I think this PR is finished and needs review. It does two things:

1) Separates SUPPORT_POWER_TIMER widget definition into ingame-player and ingame-observer. This makes it possible to define different bound offsets for observers who don't have support power icons.
2) Organizes support power countdown timers in player teams. It looks like this:

![sptimer-simple](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6599106/8504020/1794039e-21d2-11e5-86cd-9421c404b220.png)

Power names and remaining times are aligned dynamically.
This map can be used to quickly test the timer display:
http://resource.openra.net/maps/3506/

Possible changes/improvements that could be done:
- Change `class Text` to `struct` as suggested by @Unit158. :white_check_mark: 
- Calculate `maxPlayerWidth` once in the constructor for all players and not every tick for the players that have a support power.
- Calculate `maxPowerWidth` once in the constructor for all buildable support powers in current map or mod, instead of every tick. (I don't know how to do this.)
- Store `playersByTeam` in a data structure like Dictionary<> instead of querying it every tick. :white_check_mark: Or cache `IOrderedEnumerable`. (I don't know how to do this.)

I can't think of anything else... OK, let's discuss!

Here are Visual Studio profiling results (.vsps files) for bleed and this PR:
https://drive.google.com/folderview?id=0B_dMvsHPqPZkfnJhR1Ryck44Szh4aDhJMjNHd2oySnpsbDNxdjd4UEc1MVhzY0NVcUE0RHM&usp=sharing
Looks ok to me. :+1: / :white_check_mark:
Do we want this feature?  The reception has been luke-warm at best.
Doesn't this improve the timers considerably? Without team grouping and player names, I find the timers to be not that useful.

That is the open question which nobody has really asked yet.  It adds more details, but it also adds a lot more visual clutter to the screen.  If people don't feel that extra detail is needed, then the additional content could be taken as an overall negative instead of improvement.

I'm going to day that player names are definitely a good thing as our colour validation is simply ass. Teams are a bit overkill but whatever.

On 2015-07-13, at 9:16 AM, Paul Chote notifications@github.com wrote:

> That is the open question which nobody has really asked yet. It adds more details, but it also adds a lot more visual clutter to the screen. If people don't feel that extra detail is needed, then the additional content could be taken as an overall negative instead of improvement.
> 
> â€•
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.

Popular opinion has been that we do not want this.
Also :-1: until you can convince me this really needs `Tick()` _and_ `Draw()` methods.
And also I've listed reasons to -1 this like 6 times already.
I'm worried about that this can and will also run out of screen, increasing #7855 just even further.
If we remove the `Team` stuff this is kinda just a bigger version of #6282.

I don't think team labels add that much to the length of the text. There are usually two teams... If that's a problem, team labels could be omitted if total number of teams exceeds a set number.

It is better to have separate Tick and Draw methods. It allows for separation of tasks. Tick does game state dependent logic, generates the actual text that will be drawn. Draw is only responsible for drawing on screen. It gets a list of texts and draws them. This has benefits for the following cases:
- ~~When there is lag and Tick frequency is lower than Draw.~~
- ~~When game is paused. Tick stops, Draw continues~~
- ~~If in the future, Tick and Draw frequencies are decoupled, Draw could run at much higher rate than Tick. I think currently it runs with the same frequency as Tick (when there's no lag).~~

The other reason you listed is that this is more complicated than the version you implemented. If that is so, you should open a PR for it so we have a better implementation. It was nice of you to write that code to help me and I got some ideas from it. But what do you want now?

Apart from all that, the more important issue with support power timers is that drawing that text consumes 15% of CPU time according to the profiling results I posted above. If those numbers are correct, there is a problem with text drawing code. Maybe until that is fixed, countdown timers could be shown in a menu widget?
OpenRA.Graphics.SpriteFont.DrawTextWithContrast() consumes more than 14%.
I ran another profiling test and Draw() of SupportPowerTimerWidget uses 18.46% :worried:
